On 23/01/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
> Speaking as =
one of those professionals, in a desktop or server
> environment buying RAM=
 is cheaper than almost any other alternative.
> Most especially it's cheap=
er than rewriting the code to use less memory.
>
> Frankly, I'd fire a cons=
ultant who recommended continued hacking at $80
> an hour to save a byte he=
re or a byte there instead of spending a few
> bucks to upgrade the RAM. In=
 2006 anyone who's running a desktop or a
> server with less than a gigabyt=
e of RAM is being penny wise and very
> pound foolish.

Like all things, th=
is depends on context. If you're writing an
application that will dominate =
the user environment, yes, being memory
hungry isn't a crime. If it needs t=
o co-exist with several other
applications, then it is.

A server app runni=
ng on a dedicated box can do what it wants. A Java
GUI app to process shipp=
ing orders that needs to be able to accessed
along with Word documents, Exc=
el spreadsheets, and Outlook all runing
as well needs to be more parsimonio=
us. A SWT application designed to
run as a status-bar extension probably ca=
n't even afford the overhead
of the JVM.

Even if the application is "worth=
y" of the extra memory, it may not be
cheaper to give it the memory. If you=
 intend to deploy the application
to 10,000 machines in a corporate environ=
ment, the $50,000+ in parts
the memory upgrade will cost (before installati=
on!) lets you afford a
few _months_ of improving the memory usage.

Context=
 is crucial in any optimisation debate.

--
               "Software is too=
 expensive to build cheaply"
